results.title: The Family
results.creator_credit: Herbert Kerkow and United States. Army
results.brief_description: Family life as lived by a father, mother, two children and a grandmother is depicted. They are not in affluent circumstances and conflicts arise because the father wants to repair the house, mother wants a sewing machine, and the daughter a ball dress. They get together and talk out their problems; by so doing they strengthen the bonds of family life and create a sense of security among themselves.

results.title: La Familie Martin
results.brief_description: Introduces a typical Parisian family of mother, father, two sons and a daughter and tells the story of the daughter’s return by air from a holiday in England. Commentary and dialogue in French.

results.title: Une Famille Bretonne
results.brief_description: Part of the French Language Series, this is the story of the film “French children” told in simple French by a teacher-narrator, born in France. Told in the present tense and avoiding all subjunctives, the narration is levelled at the needs of beginners and provides practice in the understanding of spoken French. The film portrays family life on a farm in Brittany. It illustrates the work of each member of the family and includes scenes of the village school and a neighbouring town.

results.title: Families get angry
results.creator_credit: Delton Cook, John Simons and Oxford Films (U.S.)
results.brief_description: A family quarrel begins when the father in a black, low-income family is trying to stretch too little money to pay too many bills. The two children are strongly affected by their parents’ conflict.

results.title: The Fallout atom
results.creator_credit: Harold Mayer, Michael Sklar and Columbia Broadcasting System
results.brief_description: An examination of the scientific facts of human radiation filmed at the Argonne National Laboratory of the AEC in Lemont, Ill. Dr John E. Rose attempts to find out how much radioactive material the human body possesses naturally, how much we have been exposed to as a result of nuclear bomb tests, and the effects of radiation on health and life. Shows the tests of two groups of human guinea pigs; one group - radium dial painters who literally ate radium 30 years ago, and another group whose everyday drinking water has a higher-than-average percentage of radium.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Harold Mayer, Michael Sklar and Columbia Broadcasting System

results.title: Falling from ladders
results.creator_credit: Mort Ransen, John Kemeny, Joseph Koenig, Tom Daly, National Film Board of Canada and Svenska filminstitutet
results.brief_description: Simply by putting about twenty Swedish men, women and young people in front of his camera and having them read aloud from the Statistical Year Book, filmmaker Mort Ransen has recorded a wide range of impressions of Sweden’s economic and social existence. Quotations vary from the whole gamut of exports and imports, marriages formed or dissolved, to the number of people who fall from ladders annually.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Mort Ransen, John Kemeny, Joseph Koenig, Tom Daly, National Film Board of Canada and Svenska filminstitutet

results.title: Intolerance: the fall of Babylon. - [Edited version]
results.creator_credit: Paul Killiam, Saul J. Turell and Sterling Educational Films
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “History of the Motion Picture”.
Still acknowledged as the biggest `spectacular’ of all, this section of the D.W. Griffith production has enormous full-scale sets of old Babylon, fantastic battle scenes, thousands of extras, and amazingly realistic reconstructions of the life, habits and customs of those ancient times. Includes Constance Talmadge, Seena Owen, Elmo Lincoln, Alfred Paget, Elmer Clinton and Wallace Reid.
